title: Is it normal for an attorney to charge an extra fee for a reaffirmation agreement on a car?
question: The extra fee is $150.00
answers: It is permissible for an attorney to charge reasonable fees for additional work beyond the scope of representation as described in your attorney client fee agreement. I'm assuming this is the debtor's (your) attorney. I generally do not advise, nor sign off on, reaffirmation agreements for debtors, as it is practically never in the debtors best interest to agree to pay a debt, which would otherwise be discharged in the bankruptcy they just filed.

Yes, it is totally normal. In fact, that is a pretty standard rate. There are some lawyers who will not prepare and certify these reaffirmation agreements because once submitted and approved by the assigned judge, you are obligating yourself to pay this debt and cannot be discharge in the instant Chapter 7 case. If there is a significant difference between your Schedule I and Schedule J, making the difference between the two negative, you are likely to have a judge disapprove of your request to reaffirm your car at your reaffirmation hearing. This is because requesting a reaffirmation under these circumstance creates a presumption of hardship. However, some judges take the position that you are a grown-up and should understand the consequences of reaffirming a car loan if fully explained to you. If you filed in "pro se," the judge would have the task of explaining to you exactly that.
Good Luck.
***This is just general legal information, not advice specific to you in your case. There is no attorney-client privilege here.***

If the attorney is doing additional work, why wouldn't you expect to pay for the work? Reaffirmations require reviewing a contract, submitting the contract to the court, and in many instances, appearing in court for a hearing. $150 sounds way cheap to me!

I'm assuming you're talking about YOUR (the debtor's) attorney. Whether it is "normal" or not isn't really an appropriate question.

It's certainly reasonable for the attorney to ask for that, unless your retainer agreement provides otherwise. Aside from the extra time the attorney takes in dealing with the reaffirmation process, he is also undertaking a liability for attesting to your ability to make the payments under the reaffirmation agreement. Personally, I won't sign off on them for any amount of money (well, maybe there's some amount I'd agree to).

Can you tell us more about what this agreement is all about?
Is this related to a BK filing?
Is this your atty or the bank's atty?
It is normal in the Northern District of Illinois - Chicago.

This practice–among creditor attorneys– is not uncommon in Missouri, Eastern District, Bankruptcy where I practice. The prices typically is $150.

As to an attorney representing the bankruptcy debtor, I do not usually charge extra for reaffirmation agreements, but it would be permitted under local rules.
